The **acid blob**, b, is an [amoeboid](/wiki/Amoeboid "Amoeboid") [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") in [NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack"). It is the first [acidic](/wiki/Acidic "Acidic") monster most players will encounter, and also likely the first [amorphous](/wiki/Amorphous "Amorphous") monster as well. Acid blobs do no damage on their own, but have an acid-splashing [passive attack](/wiki/Passive_attack "Passive attack") that can [corrode](/wiki/Corrode "Corrode") [weapons](/wiki/Weapons "Weapons") and [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor").

Acid blob [corpses](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") are [vegan](/wiki/Vegan "Vegan") and have some fairly unique traits: they are always fit for sacrifice, and do not become [tainted](/wiki/Tainted "Tainted") from aging similar to [lichen](/wiki/Lichen "Lichen") and [lizard](/wiki/Lizard "Lizard") corpses, though they will still rot away like other corpses.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) Eating an acid blob's corpse will deal 1d15 damage unless you are [acid resistant](/wiki/Acid_resistant "Acid resistant") - a [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") of acid blob is safe to eat.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

## Generation

Acid blobs may generate as [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") for [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") characters. Reading any [scroll of create monster](/wiki/Scroll_of_create_monster "Scroll of create monster") while [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") will create at least 13 acid blobs.

## Strategy

Acid blobs will act the same as any other monster when hostile, but are ultimately harmless - however, attacking them poses a threat to an inexperienced and/or low-level player, and their amorphous forms allow them to ooze under doors and block a player's path. For some early characters, it is best to dispatch hostile blobs from a distance with disposable projectiles like [rocks](/wiki/Rocks "Rocks"), or non-[iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") projectiles such as [elven daggers](/wiki/Elven_dagger "Elven dagger"). Wands and spells can work, but are better saved for more direct threats. If you have enough HP to survive a few splashes of acid, then use a disposable/non-iron weapon, attack bare-handed, or simply [kick](/wiki/Kick "Kick") them; the acid splash may still affect any corrosion-vulnerable armor.

Neutral players dealing with peaceful acid blobs blocking their path will want to let their pet handle the dirty work instead, and can use movement [m](/wiki/M "M") to try and nudge the blob into an open room if all else fails. Angering a peaceful acid blob incurs the usual -1 penalty to [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record"), or a -5 penalty if you kill the blob without angering it (e.g. via [force bolt](/wiki/Force_bolt "Force bolt") for [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")) - be sure to [farlook](/wiki/Farlook "Farlook") an acid blob to determine if it is peaceful.

Past the early game, acid blobs are little more than a nuisance that can occasionally erode weapons and armor if a player is careless in dispatching them, and proper erode-proofing mitigates even that annoyance. However, acid blob corpses have some value throughout the game, both as long-lasting sacrifice fodder and a means of curing [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") - acid blob tins can cure it without dealing acid damage, but may take too long to safely open unless [blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed").

Later in the game, players may employ confused readings of scrolls of create monster to fill up a dungeon level with acid blobs and prevent especially dangerous hostile monsters from approaching; this is also occasionally employed to stop the [Riders](/wiki/Riders "Riders") on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") from reviving.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Peacecful monsters can be displaced the same as pets, allowing neutral players to move past peaceful acid blobs in their way.

## History

The acid blob has been present in the game since hack121, a variant of [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"). From this version to [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e"), acid blobs used the a glyph.

In early versions of *NetHack* such as [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d"), acid blobs were [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to eat rather than acidic, and their acidic passive attacks decreased weapon enchantment since corrosion was not yet introduced.

## Variants

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), acid blobs are classified as [primordials](/wiki/Primordial "Primordial").

Fourteen acid blobs are placed on the level containing the branch entrance to the [Chaos Temple Quest](/wiki/Chaos_Temple_Quest "Chaos Temple Quest") (or "chaos1") if it is generated in the dungeon.

## Encyclopedia entry

- *See the [encyclopedia entry for amoeboid](/wiki/Amoeboid#Encyclopedia_entry "Amoeboid").*
